comments.commentBody: We are heading for the same Constitutional Crises we did in the last shutdown. The Republicans hated Pres. Clinton and the Republicans hate Pres. What's more, it all but assures that the same tactic will be repeated this time next year, probably as part of a showboating exercise designed to get out the Tea Party vote.

Yikes! Your understanding of math is minimal.

It is a zero sum game.

It is a probability distribution.

There is a top and bottom.

Jessica: "There is no reason that everyone who has the ability can't go to 'elite' schools".

You don't bother defining what "elite" means. If some number of academically qualified high schoolers deem "elite" to mean Princeton and nowhere else, and that number is greater than the number of spaces Princeton has available for the incoming class, your assertion fails.

Moreover, "elite" schools, depending on how you define them, are expensive. Not everyone will be able to score scholarships and grants, or be able to make up the difference with student loans (ignoring what a burden those can become after graduation) or part-time employment.

Your heart's in the right place, but you take too simplistic a view of the problem.

I intentionally hedged because I do not think that the bell curve has much relevance here, but couldn't come up with a way of expressing it as clearly without some reference.

Use of the bell curve in this context implies that a group of people will be always be unqualified for "elite colleges" even if everyone is a genius. The discussions seem to peg it at the top 10% of college applicants. Why? Where did that number come from? Qualifications for students are whatever you make them. Yes, not everyone is "elite, but there are more "elite" students out there than places for them, so the colleges are upping the requirements on whims and leaving many very, very talented people in the cold.

Susan,

What do you mean by "so miserable?" How about the lives of those at the bottom of the ladder being good and the bottom not being very far down. This happens in other countries. I hope you misspoke here.

RS,
Education is NOT a zero-sum game. Everyone doesn't have to be a genius or mover and shaker but everyone should get the education they are capable of.

This is not a zero-sum game. Why does anyone have to move down the ladder? Does income have to be a bell-curve? No. What if the whole curve moved and a larger percentage of people were at the top.

Students in lower socio-economic groups don't make it to elite colleges unless they have super skills because the colleges put too much weight on extra-curricular activities in high-school. Why does a really good scientist have to also be a musician? Why does an artist have to be good at sports and spend summers helping the poor? Only well-to-do children in well-to-do communities have the parental resources to provide enriched extra-curricular activities.

Get rid of those "requirements" and you will see a rise in students from down the ladder. And you should also see some happier, less stressed students and adults everywhere.

The dollar was reserve currency mostly for lack of an alternative. At the start of WW2, the other major currencies ended free convertibility as part of wartime financial controls. There was no other convertible currency trading in volume. The dollar was it, unless you loaded gold bars on ships (some did).

There still is a lack of a good alternative. The alternatives with enough volume to serve the purpose all have serious flaws. For example, we can't use the Swiss currency because it is too small. The Euro is in crisis. The Chinese are not freely convertible.

This might drive the world to a high cost new alternative method that is not a national currency at all, like one of the basket theories, or a large volume universal commodity like oil, or to a marginal currency like the Yen (modest volume, troubled economy behind it).

It is a problem without a good answer.

However, we have now made it a problem, a big money problem. When an answer does appear, our reserve currency status will be lost. We've bungled it so badly we have the world begging for an alternative.
Then perhaps the Senate and the President should refrain from doing anything that will reduce the world's confidence in the dollar.

The fastest way to push the rest of the world to work faster towards a new world reserve currency is to reduce their faith in the current one. The U.S. dollar has only been the world's major reserve currency since WWII (prior to WWII it was the pound sterling). Given a fiscal crisis through an inability of the U.S. federal legislative bodies to work together, and I think that Europe, Russia, China, Japan, the northern neighbour, the BRIC and the Asian Pacific Rim countries might decide to make that a priority right quick.

The result for all levels of U.S. government, headquartered companies and U.S. consumers will be an increased cost of borrowing.

The lower cost of borrowing available to all U.S. based companies and governments is a considerable competitive advantage. It's going to hurt when it's gone.

Great article. While much (most) of medicine may not be strictly evidence based, the attempts to subject common or assumed practices to rigorous scientific studies elevated modern medicine beyond placebo. While it is true that we are far from knowing everything, or even much, about how things work (many diseases are "idiopathic" which is a fancy word for "unknown cause") it is the consistent revising and revisiting of theories of pathogenesis as confirmed or rejected by scientific evidence. There is a lot of observational or anecdotal "data" about therapy, that ultimately doesn't hold up when rigorously evaluated in randomized, controlled trials. We are all, patients and doctors at the bedside, susceptible to a variety of biases, but it is the randomized, clinical trials that keep us "honest" and advance medical science. We often assume that improvement that follows therapy is attributable to the therapy (http://mybetterdoctor.com/2013/04/10/post-hoc-ergo-propter-hoc/), or that all Western medical advice is based on good science (http://mybetterdoctor.com/2013/08/28/evidence-free-pregnancy-advice/).

It was encouraging to hear Bill De Blasio extolling the virtues of Fiorello LaGuardia, "The Little Flower", all 4 foot 11 inches of him.  Mayor LaGuardia was one of the nation's greatest Mayors and the hope here is that Mr. De Blasio  evolves into "The Big Flower", all 6 foot 5 inches of him.  To do that he he will have to lower expectations while raising the quality of New York's tough citizenry's quality of life.  Having grown up in Bayside, Queens, attended college in Brooklyn, lived in 4 boroughs (all except S.I.), drove a taxi for 4 years at night as a college student, worked in New York's City Hall for one Mayor and New York's Department of Transportation under two others, I have learned one essential truth about the "Big Apple".  New York first and foremost is a money city overwhelmed  with the culture of money.   Being Mayor of New York is a brutal job and not for the innocent or faint of heart.   It requires political cunning, a strong constitution, an acute intelligence, a thick skin and patience.  Mr. De Blasio has shown extraordinary political skill in his career that began in City Hall under Mayor Dinkins to bring to him to this time and place.  I believe Mr. De Blasio will be Mayor De Blasio in a few weeks and if that should happen he will have to know the limits as well as the extent of his authority and how he can politically enhance it.  The current Mayor, elected three times, did honor to his City and his office.  The Big Flower will want to build on that.

The simple fact is, the ACA is merely a set of minor health insurance regulatory tweaks, prohibiting some recent "innovations" that were particularly abusive to policyholders, and requiring a certain standard for coverage and efficiency -- 80% of premiums must be spent by insurers on the actual provision of care. It is a real stretch to glorify it with the moniker "reform."

The Constitution SPECIFICALLY grants the responsibility for the regulation of interstate commerce to the Federal government, and all of the major health insurers are definitely interstate in their commercial nature.

This is not "Federal intrusion." This is a constitutional mandated responsibility of our Federal government.
Let them resign their jobs if they think govt. is so wrong.

They are convinced that once The People taste the sweet nectar of federally subsidized healthcare, there will be no turning back. There also will be no room for a Republican Party as millions more will vote Democrat.

Some of them probably do understand what a default would do to the world's economy. But they feel the costs are worth it to stop our downward spiral to the communes. This will force them to accept their irrelevance. Desperate people do desperate things and you don't get much more desperate that that.
